Queue

What is Queue?


A queue is an linear data structure, commonly used in most of the programming languages. It follow a paticular order in which operations are performed. It allows adding and removing elements in a particular order. Every time an element is added it goes at the beginning of the queue, and only element that can be removed is the element that is at the end of the queue.
Good example of a queue is a queue of customers in a supermarket's billing counter, where the customer that came first are served first.
The only difference between stacks and queues is in removing. In stacks we only remove element that is at the beginning whereas in queues we only remove element that is at the end.

Features

  • Queue is ordered list
  • It follows FIFO (First In First Out) or LILO (Last In Last Out) order
  • enqueue() function is used to insert a new element in the stack
  • dequeue() fuction is used to remove an element from the stack
  • Both insertion and removal are of order O(1) and searching is of order O(n)

Implementation


            //In Queue, you add at the end and delete at the beginning
            #include< stdio.h>
            #include< stdlib.h>
            struct node
            {
            	int data;
            	struct node* next;
            };

            // Adding an element to the Queue
            void Enqueue(struct node **head,struct node **tail,int key)
            {
            	struct node *temp;
            	temp = malloc(sizeof(struct node));
            	temp->data = key;
            	if((*head) == NULL)
            	{
            		(*tail) = temp;
            		(*head) = temp;
            	}
            	else
            	{
            		(*tail)->next = temp;
            		(*tail) = temp;
            	}

            }

            // Deleting an element from the queue
            void Dequeue(struct node **head)
            {
            	(*head) = (*head)->next;
            }

            void print(struct node *head)
            {
             	while(head != NULL)
            	{
            		printf("%d -> ",head->data);
            		head = head->next;

            	}
            	printf("\n");
            }

            int main()
            {
            	struct node *head,*tail;
            	head = NULL;
            	tail = NULL;
            	Enqueue(&head,&tail,1);
            	Enqueue(&head,&tail,2);
            	Enqueue(&head,&tail,3);
            	Enqueue(&head,&tail,4);
            	Enqueue(&head,&tail,5);
            	print(head);
            	Dequeue(&head);
            	print(head);

            	return 0;
            }
Run On IDE

Here there are two pointers, one pointing to the beginning of the queue and another pointing at the end of the queue. Queue can be formed using two stacks. Check it out how Queue using two stacks
